title: Which film will win the 2020 Oscar® for Directing?
preds: Copying Ben Zauzmer who has written a book about predicting the Oscars ' Oscarmetrics: The Math Behind the Biggest Night in Hollywood'. His model has a very good record of predicting the correct outcomes.

Chloe Zhao has picked up every other major directing prize, including the top award for the Director's Guild of America. She would also be the second woman and first woman of color to win the award at the Oscars, which could serve as a political agenda for voters.

95% Nomadland? We're being a bit silly.
GJO: 95% | Experts: 100% |MC users: 77% = Avg. 90.67% Mank:
GJO: 1% | Experts: 0% |MC users: 10% = Avg. 3.67% (Awarding an extra point for Hollywood loving films about Hollywood.) Minari:
GJO: 3% | Experts: 0% |MC users: 6% = Avg. 3% The numbers don't and won't add up accounting for points awarded other pictures. Omitting those for now.
https://www.metacritic.com/feature/picks-for-who-will-win-2021-oscars?ref=hp
Nomadland seems to be marching ahead

Zhao is the strong favorite and has the sleuth of awards to prove it. Leaving some possibility for Minari's and Mank's directors because there exists talks about how well directed those movies are. To a degree so does Promising Young Woman's director but sadly I cut her odds due to the fact that historically women have not been proportionally represented among the winners. I also raised Vinterberg's probability to be above the 1% probability of a tie that I forecast.

The BAFTA for best director went to Nomadland. It also won the best picture. Seeing the results of the past 10 years, it becomes extremely likely that Nomadland will also win the Oscar for the best director and the best picture.
Chloé Zhao seems to be at the head of the table, and the closest person to her isn't for miles.

There were only six ties in history
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Academy_Award_records#Tied_winners
which would be a baseline of 0.1%, and none of these were in the "Big Five categories".
However, an unexpected tie for two likewise brillant directors may accur, or any other event that could disrupt the Academy Awards on short notice.

I have not seen any of these movies, which is in fact perfect to make a prediction based on previous results. I have checked the Oscar winners of the past 10 years and the potential correlation with the best movie, actor, actress, supporting actor and actress. Also looked at the Golden Globe winners and BAFTA winners of the past 10 years to see if there are any potential relationships to predict a winner. It is interesting to see how diverse the Oscars, Golden Globes and BAFTA winners are. Oscars:
There is a 50% chance that the winner of the best movie will also win the best director.
There is a 30% chance that the winner of the best movie will also win the best actor.
There is a 10% chance that the winner of the best movie will also win the best actress.
In the past 10 years, the winner of the best director did not get a winner for supporting actor or actress. "Another round" is not nominated for the best movie. In the past 10 years, it never happened that the best director winner did not have the movie listed as the best movie. Therefore, the chance this movie wins the best director is very low. "Nomadland" won the best director and best movie during the Golden Globes. In the past 10 years, 5 out of 10 winners of the best director at the Golden Globes also win the Oscar. What is even more interesting, there is a very strong relationship between the  Golden Globe best director winner and the winner of the best director Oscar (last year was an exception). In addition, in the past 10 years, only three times the Golden Globe best director also won the best movie and in those years the best director also won the Oscar. This makes "Nomadland" the clear favourite for this year's best director Oscar.

Academy awards often attempt to reflect the Zeitgeist, imperfectly of course and it seems highly probable that a woman director of color (well-deservedly) might win the prize. It was hard to pick between a male director of Asian origin and a white woman director. FWIW, these three movies are equally good on other parameters.

It seems Chloe Zhao is a lock given the share of her awards so far. The gossip, on the other hand, is a different story where Lee, Emerald, and even Fincher seems to be hot contenders. For this forecast, I incorporated a little bit more opinions from Gold Derby but more or less my original thinking remains the same from last forecast. I leave the 1% for the real possibility of a tie, which if it were to happen in any year this year would be ideal. The annual Oscars isn't 100 years old yet so we cannot rule out there is a 1/100 chance of a tie. It has happened in other categories during the ceremony.
They will want to give it to a female director.
This category is due to award to a female director after years of neglect

Ben Zauzmer has written a book about predicting the Oscars ' Oscarmetrics: The Math Behind the Biggest Night in Hollywood'. His model has a very good record of predicting the correct outcomes. But this is the "weirdest year of Oscar prediction". "From new eligibility rules to new BAFTA voting procedures to a new awards timeline to watching all movies at home, this will be an awards season unlike any other". These are his predictions for nominations (which we now know) overall they were accurate.
https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/predicting-this-years-oscar-nominations-using-just-math I think another article will be published shortly with his predictions for winners. I want to do my forecast before that comes out so its not complete plagiarism haha. Other predictions using modelling...
https://www.goldderby.com/gallery/2021-oscar-predictions-winners-categories/chloe-zhao-attends-the-24th-annual-gotha/
https://variety.com/feature/2021-oscars-predictions-academy-awards-nominations-1234764774/

In predicting who will win the Best Director Oscar, I compared previous Oscar winners to the equivalent winners at the Golden Globes which is held earlier in the year ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director#Multiple_wins_and_nominations
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Director Of the most recent 20 times (2000 - 2019) ->
The Golden Globe Best Director Winner Also Won the Equivalent Oscar = 10/20
The Golden Globe Best Director Winner Didn't Win the Equivalent Oscar = 9/20
The Golden Globe Best Director Winner Wasn't Nominated for Equivalent Oscar = 1/20 With Nomandland winning the 2020 Golden Globes Best Director and Oscar Nominated, this leaves only the first two options
Nomandland = 53% = 10 / (10 + 9)
Other Nominated Films = 47% = 9 / (10 + 9) My personal prediction is that neither Minari or Another Round will win and that a Female Director Winner is very likely.

Currently Zhao has the buzz, but I think Fennell could sneak in here and Nomadland gets pic. Whatever the case, my thinking right now is that (justly) there is pressure for the academy to be more proactive in awarding this prize to women and POC. I think and hope they step up to the plate, although the traditional thought would be Fincher winning for a film that's about the industry.
